Adrecon found in powershell transcripts
• PingCastle and ADRecon to perform reconnaissance of Active Directory

The attackers continued their previous discovery efforts using a PowerShell script version of ADRecon (ADRecon.ps1), which is a tool designed to gather extensive information about an Active Directory (AD) environment. The attacker followed up this action with a net scanning tool that opened connections to devices in the organization on server message block (SMB) and remote desktop protocol (RDP). For discovered devices, the attackers attempted to navigate to various network shares and used the Remote Desktop client (mstsc.exe) to sign into these devices, once again using the compromised account credentials.

Collecting domain information allowed the attackers to progress further in their attack because the said information could identify potential targets for lateral movement or those that would help the attackers distribute their ransomware payload. To do this, the attackers once again used ADRecon.ps1with numerous PowerShell cmdlets such as the following:

After gaining initial access and code execution capabilities on the affected device in the network, the threat actor performed extensive discovery to find potential desirable targets such as high-value assets and general domain information like Domain Administrator users and domain forest trust. Common native Windows tools and commands, such as systeminfo.exe, net.exe, nltest.exe, tasklist.exe, were leveraged in this phase. The threat actor also utilized open-source tools like ossec-win32 and OSQuery to query additional endpoint information. Additionally, in some of the attacks, we observed the threat actor running an obfuscated version of ADRecon.ps1 called obfs.ps1 or recon.ps1 for Active Directory reconnaissance.

Evidence of this execution was an obfuscated PowerShell script named ‘C:\osit\r.ps1’ that was found on a local server. Although the file no longer existed after execution – presumably it was deleted by the threat actor – by analysing the PowerShell logs, it was possible to recover and decode the content of the file. The file was identified as ‘ADRecon’, an open-source PowerShell tool specifically designed to gather extensive information about Active Directory (AD) environments, including ACLs, DNS zones, BitLocker recovery keys, LAPS passwords, Domain accounts, and SPN credential hashes.

UNC4466 also made use of ADRecon to gather network, account, and host information in the victim’s environment. When executed by a privileged domain account, ADRecon generates several reports about the Active Directory environment, including the Trusts, Sites, Subnets, password policies, user and computer account listings. These reports can be generated in a variety of formats, including CSV, XML, JSON, and HTML.

McLellan\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e"]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003eMandiant has observed a new ALPHV (aka BlackCat ransomware) ransomware affiliate, tracked as UNC4466, target publicly exposed Veritas Backup Exec installations, vulnerable to CVE-2021-27876, CVE-2021-27877 and CVE-2021-27878, for initial access to victim environments. A commercial Internet scanning service identified over 8,500 installations of Veritas Backup Exec instances that are currently exposed to the internet, some of which may still be unpatched and vulnerable. Previous ALPHV intrusions investigated by Mandiant primarily originated from stolen credentials suggesting a shift to opportunistic targeting of known vulnerabilities. This blog post covers the UNC4466 attack lifecycle, indicators, and detection opportunities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eALPHV emerged in November 2021 as a ransomware-as-a-service that some researchers \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/blackcat-alphv-ransomware-linked-to-blackmatter-darkside-gangs/\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003ehave claimed\u003c/a\u003e is the successor to BLACKMATTER and DARKSIDE ransomware. While some ransomware operators enacted rules to avoid impacting critical infrastructure and health entities, ALPHV has \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/blackcat-ransomware-claims-attack-on-european-gas-pipeline/\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003econtinued\u003c/a\u003e to target these \u003ca href\u003d\"https://therecord.media/sun-pharma-india-ransomware-attack\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003esensitive\u003c/a\u003e industries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eTimeline\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn March 2021, Veritas \u003ca href\u003d\"https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/security/VTS21-001\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003epublished\u003c/a\u003e an advisory reporting three critical vulnerabilities in Veritas Backup Exec 16.x, 20.x and 21.x.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOn September 23, 2022, a METASPLOIT module was released which exploits these vulnerabilities and creates a session which the threat actor can use to interact with the victim system.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eOn October 22, 2022, Mandiant first observed exploitation of the Veritas vulnerabilities in the wild.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAttack Phases\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInitial Compromise and Establish Foothold\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn late 2022, UNC4466 gained access to an internet-exposed Windows server, running Veritas Backup Exec version 21.0 using the Metasploit module `exploit/multi/veritas/beagent_sha_auth_rce`. Shortly after, the Metasploit persistence module was invoked to maintain persistent access to the system for the remainder of this intrusion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInternal Reconnaissance\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAfter gaining access to the Veritas Backup Exec server, UNC4466 used Internet Explorer, the browser installed by default on older Windows systems, to download Famatech’s Advanced IP Scanner from its website, hxxps://download.advanced-ip-scanner[.]com. This tool is capable of scanning individual IP addresses or IP address ranges for open ports, and returns hostnames, operating system and hardware manufacturer information.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC4466 also made use of \u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/adrecon/ADRecon\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003eADRecon\u003c/a\u003e to gather network, account, and host information in the victim’s environment. When executed by a privileged domain account, ADRecon generates several reports about the Active Directory environment, including the Trusts, Sites, Subnets, password policies, user and computer account listings. These reports can be generated in a variety of formats, including CSV, XML, JSON, and HTML.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eIngress Tool Transfer\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC4466 made heavy use of the Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) to download additional tools such as LAZAGNE, LIGOLO, WINSW, RCLONE, and finally the ALPHV ransomware encryptor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCommand and Control\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC4466 leveraged SOCKS5 tunneling to communicate with compromised systems in the victim network. This technique is typically used to evade network defenses or other preventative network controls. Two separate tools were deployed to execute this technique, \u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/sysdream/ligolo\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003eLIGOLO\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/kost/revsocks\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003eREVSOCKS\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEscalate Privileges\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe threat actor utilized multiple credential access tools, including Mimikatz, LaZagne and Nanodump to gather clear-text credentials and credential material.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn November 2022, UNC4466 utilized the MIMIKATZ Security Support Provider injection module (`MISC::MemSSP`). This module collects credentials in clear text as they are used, by manipulating the Local Security Authority Server Service (LSASS) on victim systems. This module creates a file named `C:\\Windows\\System32\\mimilsa.log`.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e \u003c/p\u003e"]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,""],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/alphv-image1-mimikatz_jwhj.max-1000x1000.png",null,null,"https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/alphv-image1-mimikatz_jwhj.max-1000x1000.png"],null,3]]],[null,null,null,null,null,null,null,null,[[[null,""],["https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/alphv-image2-mimilsa.max-800x800.png","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/alphv-image2-mimilsa.max-800x800.png 800w, https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/alphv-image2-mimilsa.max-800x800.png 800w"," 800px,  800px","https://storage.googleapis.com/gweb-cloudblog-publish/images/alphv-image2-mimilsa.max-800x800.png"],null,3]]],[null,null,[null,[null,"\u003cp\u003e[\u003ca href\u003d\"https://github.com/helpsystems/nanodump\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003eNanodump\u003c/a\u003e] was also used to dump LSASS memory. Like the examples shown on Helpsystems' GitHub page, the output file specified was a file in the `C:\\Windows\\Temp` directory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDefense Evasion\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring operations, UNC4466 takes steps to evade detection. Apart from clearing event logs, UNC4466 also used the built in Set-MpPrefernce cmdlet to disable Microsoft Defender’s real-time monitoring capability.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003epowershell.exe Set-MpPreference -DisableRealtimeMonitoring 1 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCommand and Control\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC4466 made use of BITS transfers (using the Start-BitsTransfer PowerShell cmdlet) to download various resources to the staging directory `c:\\ProgramData`. Using this technique, SOCKS5 tunneling tools, REVSOCKS and LIGOLO were downloaded from their official GitHub repositories.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eComplete Mission\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC4466 deploys the Rust-based ALPHV ransomware. In Late 2022, UNC4466 added immediate tasks to the default domain policy. These tasks were configured to perform actions which disabled security software, downloaded the ALPHV encryptor, then execute it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eExposure\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs of this blog post's date, one commercial Internet scanning service reported over 8500 IP addresses which advertise the \"Symantec/Veritas Backup Exec ndmp\" service on the default port 10000, as well as port 9000 and port 10001. While this search result does not directly identify vulnerable systems, as the application versions were not identifiable, it demonstrates the prevalence of Internet exposed instances that could potentially be probed by attackers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eDetection Opportunities\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDefenders should place priority on monitoring internet-exposed Veritas Backup Exec Windows installations, for versions before 21.2. Mandiant observed the exploitation of Veritas Backup Exec can leave a noticeable imprint on the Backup Exec log files. Where feasible, these log files should be forwarded to a SIEM or similar technology which enables detection and alerting when certain events are recorded.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to any available network connection logging, Veritas Backup Exec logs will record evidence of connections to remote systems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[nnnn] YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.sss [ndmp\\ndmpsrvr]      + ndmpd.cpp (nnn):\r\n[nnnn] YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.sss [ndmp\\ndmpsrvr]      | Session 1 started\r\n[nnnn] YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.sss [ndmp\\ndmpsrvr]      - sslOpen() : Opening SSL for: 0x00000\r\n[nnnn] YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.sss [ndmp\\ndmpsrvr]      - sslOpen(): certinfo \u003d 0x00000; sslConn \u003d 0x00000\r\n[nnnn] YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.sss [ndmp\\ndmpcomm]      - ndmpRun: Control connection accepted : connection established between end-points [Server IP]:10000 and [Remote IP]:[remote port]\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"color:#5f6368;overflow-x:auto;overflow-y:hidden;width:100%\"\u003e \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese connections should be triaged for any unknown IP addresses. Additionally, these logs can also record the execution of suspicious pre and post backup job commands.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cpre\u003e\u003ccode\u003e[nnnn] YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.sss [ndmp\\ndmpsrvr]      - SetPreCommandEnvironment: Could not obtain the BE Job ID to pass to the command C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /c \"C:\\Windows\\Temp\\[random chars].exe\"\r\n[nnnn] YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.sss [ndmp\\ndmpsrvr]      - Could not obtain the BE Job Name to pass to the command C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /c \"C:\\Windows\\Temp\\[random chars].exe\"\r\n[nnnn] YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.sss [ndmp\\ndmpsrvr]      - At least one of the Pre / Post Command environment variables could not be set\r\n[nnnn] YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS.sss [ndmp\\ndmpcomm]      - ndmp_readit: Caught message on closed connection. Socket 0x8e0 len 0x0\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\n\u003cdiv style\u003d\"color:#5f6368;overflow-x:auto;overflow-y:hidden;width:100%\"\u003e \u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUNC4466\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDS0015 - Application log\r\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eBackup Exec logs\r\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eConnections to unknown IP addresses\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSuspicious pre or post job commands being set (SetPreCommandEnvironment/ SetPostCommandEnvironment). E.g: C:\\Windows\\System32\\cmd.exe /c \"C:\\Windows\\Temp\\\u003cem\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eUNKNOWN_EXEC\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/em\u003e.exe”\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWindows Event Logs\r\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSuspicious BITS transfers with the source argument targeting unknown hosts and GitHub repositories.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003ePre-ransomware activity: deletion of volume shadow copies\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDS0017 – Command\r\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDisabling AMSI: use of Set-MpPreference PowerShell cmdlet\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIngress tool transfer: Use of Start-BitsTransfer PowerShell cmdlet\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDS0022 – File\r\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNew Executables created in staging directories: C:\\ProgramData, C:\\Windows\\Temp, C:\\Windows\\Tasks\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDS0024 – Windows Registry\r\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eModification of Registry run keys\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eOutlook\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMandiant recommends implementing secure access controls, segmenting networks, enabling multi-factor authentication, and regularly testing and evaluating backup strategies to limit the impact of a ransomware attack. Additionally, organizations should inventory externally facing services and reduce the \u003ca href\u003d\"https://cloud.google.com/security/products/attack-surface-management\" rel\u003d\"noopener\" target\u003d\"_blank\"\u003eattack surface\u003c/a\u003e available to attackers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eAcknowledgements\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith special thanks to Nick Richard for
